“when participants are instructed to be-creative, the correlation between DT and gc and DT and gf was quite similar. Notably, the usually high correlation between gf and gc (r ≈ .60–.70; e.g., Bryan and Mayer 2020) could preclude finding a differential pattern for these intelligence facets. Hence, it seems that gc, namely knowledge, is required as a basic prerequisite and that gf is required to form and evaluate ideas when participants are explicitly instructed to be creative. In addition, the fact that gc and DT are correlated indicates that knowledge is required for DT, which supports the historical view of Mednick (1962). This knowledge could be used to simply recall relevant solutions (e.g., Miroshnik and Shcherbakova 2019), or provide the conceptual elements to be combined to original ideas. It must not be overlooked that by asking participants to produce many ideas, a DT test resembles verbal fluency tasks (Nusbaum et al. 2014). Beauducel and Kersting’s (2002) view that verbal fluency tasks are markers for gc would have suggested that DT and gc correlate more strongly (as compared to the DT–g or DT–gf correlations) when be-fluent instruction and fluency scoring are used to assess DT. However, this specific proposition was not supported in this study.”

“The correlations did not generally differ whether a be-fluent or a be-creative instruction (or any other variant of a hybrid instruction) is given (i.e., we did not find a main effect of instruction). However, correlations increased for the be-creative instruction when DT responses were scored for originality (i.e., in case of instruction-scoring fit) compared to fluency scorings when be-fluent instructions were used. This pattern has been expected by Silvia (2015). Be creative instructions are thought to induce more cognitively demanding strategies and thus increase the relevance of intelligence and executive control. In addition, the intelligence–DT correlation was also found to be stronger for the combination of becreative instructions and originality scoring as compared to be-creative instructions and fluency scoring. Clearly, the interaction of instruction and DT outcome has an impact on the relationship between intelligence and DT. Instructing participants to be-creative leads to more sophisticated responses, whereas instructing participants to be-fluent influences the number of responses.”

“Correlations in game-like instructions dropped to a small effect size that was nonsignificant. Compared to the test-like settings (or strategy instructions), it seems that under game-like instructions, the relationship between intelligence and DT diminishes. However, it remains unclear to what extent the testing situation influences the relationship between intelligence and DT. Affective/conative factors like current motivation, time pressure, or test anxiety may play a major role when assessing DT. For example, Byron et al. (2010) ran a meta-analysis on the relationship between stressors and creativity and found that when participants expect an evaluation, their creative performance is influenced in an inverted Ushaped manner. Strong evaluative stress or the absence of an evaluation of the performance hinders creative performance, whereas minor levels of evaluative stress support creative performance. Test situations imply the evaluation of the outcome and might be responsible for better performance. Since a considerable part of the participants are students, it can be assumed that they are familiar with test settings and that the expected evaluation of their results may have motivated them to give their best. On the other hand, the evaluative component is absent in a game-like setting and may hinder creative performance. In fact, playing a game does not necessarily stimulate the motivation to perform well. Furthermore, there were no time-constraints for the tasks in the game-like setting. What is more, game-like conditions can also drastically vary from study to study. Thus, not all studies with gamelike conditions rely on the same approach (see Said-Metwaly et al. 2017).”

“t was studied if modalities of DT and intelligence measures and their interplay affected the relationship between DT and intelligence. However, tests of this moderator were rather inconclusive (i.e., findings were not robust), and future primary studies are clearly needed to shed more light into the issue. As a more general point, it should be noted that common definitions of DT task modality just refer to the content modality of task items and responses, which does not necessarily define the modality of cognitive processes involved in task processing (Benedek and Fink 2019). Especially verbal DT tasks appear to be a quite heterogeneous group, encompassing tasks that require to work creatively with words (e.g., metaphor tasks) or objects (e.g., Alternate Uses Task). Neuroscientific investigations have shown that divergent thinking commonly implicates visual and motor activity, pointing to the involvement of mental simulations (e.g., object manipulations) and visually guided search processes even for verbal material (Benedek et al. 2020; Matheson and Kenett 2020).”

“Even though this meta-analysis has been prepared carefully in view of the current theories of DT and intelligence research, some limitations must be noted. Several studies did not report sufficient information on DT and intelligence tests, which made the coding procedure difficult. As a result, many intelligence tests were coded with g since there was no other information available. Sometimes it remained unclear which instruction was given in DT tests and, more importantly, how DT outcomes were scored. Consequently, coding might have been more detailed if more information had been provided. With regard to DT outcomes, a fully differentiated coding was not possible. All subjective scorings were subsumed under the DT outcome originality. However, the procedures were not similar in all studies. Splitting up subjective scorings into smaller categories might have provided more insight into the different scoring methods (i.e., topscoring, snapshot scoring) that are currently being discussed (Reiter-Palmon et al. 2019). It should further be mentioned that explicit instructions to focus on an aspect of creativity (e.g., “be creative”, “be original”) vary in terms of their exact wording (Acar et al. 2020; Runco et al. 2005). In the current work, we did not further distinguish between these subtleties. The main difference between be-creative and be-original instructions, for example, is the wording and while theoretically “creative” does not mean the same thing as “original”, it is far less clear if participants’ understanding of these words reflects the theoretical understanding of creativity researchers. Hence, it is an open question if these nuances in the instructions lead to a different understanding of the task.”

title: The role of memory in creative ideation

annotations.text: “we propose a memory in creative ideation (MemiC) framework that describes how creative ideas arise across four distinguishable stages of memory search, candidate idea construction, novelty evaluation and effectiveness evaluation.”

“the highly influential associative theory of creativity assumes that creative ideas result from spontaneous memory activation and recombination of memory elements in new and effective ways33. It was further proposed that combinations of more remote elements result in more creative ideas (also known as the remote associates view34), and that differences in semantic memory organization (flatter associative hierarchies) thus account for higher individual creativity35.”

“By contrast, the expertise view assumes that, especially in experts, the presentation of a problem results in retrieval of domain-specific knowledge (narrow associates), which is considered a more structured process guided by established associative connections compared with that in the remote associates view34. These associative theories have received some empirical support in the creativity literature by studies showing that creative ideation is guided by properties of semantic memory — the conceptual knowledge about the meaning of words and objects — such as category structure and domain knowledge36,37. Yet several notable discoveries in the cognitive science and neuroscience of creativity indicate that creative ideation is neither limited to merely spontaneous memory activation nor limited to semantic memory alone as assumed by the associative theory of creativity. A comprehensive account of creative ideation must accommodate the four major insights regarding memory and creative ideation discussed below.”

“First, creative ideation is supported by controlled memory retrieval. Attributing creative ideation solely to spontaneous memory activation32,35 does not account for the strong and robust association between creative ideation and cognitive control reported over the last decade38,39. Research consistently finds that creative ideation is predicted by executive abilities9,40, fluid and crystallized intelligence41,42, and especially broad retrieval ability22,43–45 — the goal-directed search and retrieval of information from semantic memory.”

“Further studies showed that individuals often adopt cognitive strategies involving cued memory search in creative ideation46–48. The substantial evidence for the role of cognitive control in creative ideation led to the development of the executive or controlled-attention theory of creativity, which assumes that creative ideation involves and benefits from goaldirected, strategic processes49.”

“Creative ideation refers to the cognitive activity of producing novel and effective solutions (that is, creative ideas). Creative ideation is typically examined with divergent thinking tasks that pose openended problems and ask individuals to think in different directions to find creative solutions5, which requires a goal-directed application of imagination.”

“divergent thinking tasks differ from convergent thinking tasks that require finding a single correct solution, such as those commonly used in intelligence tests. For example, a classic test of divergent thinking is the alternate uses task, in which individuals are asked to find creative uses for everyday objects (such as a car tyre)6. Divergent thinking test performance can be measured by scoring the quantity (fluency and flexibility of ideas) and the quality (originality and creativity of ideas) of responses produced by an individual in a given time period7, which is considered a valid index of human creative cognitive potential as it predicts real-life creative achievement8,9. Creative ideation — as measured with divergent thinking tasks — is the most thoroughly studied aspect of creative cognition to date10,11 and is broadly viewed as a central aspect of human creativity.”

“Whereas memory provides the building blocks of new ideas, coming up with something new is counteracted by the tendency to retrieve the most dominant, and thus unoriginal, information from memory16. In other words, what is highly effective in most other cognitive activities (for example, when meeting a friend we want to quickly recall their name rather than their favourite colour) undermines creative ideation and can even result in cognitive fixation17–19. In summary, memory appears to have a dual role for creative ideation as the foundation of creative ideas but also as a potentially constraining factor20.”

“reative ideas arise from the interplay of associative, spontaneous and largely automatic unconscious processes with controlled, goal-directed and largely deliberate conscious processes49–53 (Fig. 1).”

“Second, creative ideation involves both semantic and episodic memory. The associative theory and other existing theories of creativity54,55 focus exclusively on semantic memory, but fail to acknowledge the role of episodic memory — the collection and retrieval of personal events and experiences — in creativity56.”

“much evidence for the involvement of episodic memory in creative ideation exists, such as consistent associations between episodic retrieval specificity and creative performance57,58, substantial overlaps in neural activation during creative ideation and episodic memory tasks59–61, and impairments of performance in both creative ideation and episodic specificity after temporary disruption of hippocampal brain networks by transcranial magnetic stimulation62. These findings suggest that creative ideation involves episodic memory, yet the unique contributions of episodic versus semantic memory to creative ideation still need to be clarified.”

“Third, creative ideation builds on memory construction processes. Memory is increasingly acknowledged as a dynamic and constructive process63,64. Semantic memory accounts of the last decade often emphasize that conceptual representations are constantly changing and vary across different contexts, ranging from the imminent task demands to long-term experiences65,66. Moreover, successful creative problem solving has been associated with the forging of new links between previously unrelated concepts in semantic memory (such as by creating connections between problem and solution concepts), thereby resulting in changes to semantic memory structure67,68. Similarly, episodic simulation involves the flexible recombination of multimodal information to create complex mental simulations (for instance, a soccer player imagining how to execute an upcoming penalty shot). The constructive episodic simulation hypothesis69 states that retrieval from episodic memory is a constructive process supporting not only the reconstruction of past events from individual elements at the time of retrieval but also the simulation of future events and scenes3,70.”

“More generally, the constructive process of retrieval supports complex forms of imagination including creative thinking71,72. Moreover, creative performance has been linked to dynamic memory changes such as reconstructive interference73, false memories74 and even forgetting75. The similarity between memory retrieval and creative ideation is further evidenced by the presence of similar phenomena such as cognitive fixation76,77 — in which response generation gets constrained by previous solutions — and incubation effects78,79 — in which taking a break from a task overcomes cognitive fixation. Thus, the dynamic and constructive nature of memory has important implications for how knowledge is reconfigured and extended during creative ideation.”

“Last, creative ideation recruits memory at different stages. Creative ideation performance is commonly studied with divergent thinking tasks, requiring the continuous production of possible solutions to open-ended problems. Focusing only on the final output (ideas or products) of such extended divergent thinking tasks can easily obscure the specific role of memory throughout the creative ideation process10. Analyses of the time dynamics of response behaviour80,81 and the use of think-aloud protocols capturing ongoing thoughts in creative ideation studies47,82 have identified different sub-processes and strategies during creative ideation. Moreover, a few theoretical accounts have described the temporal dynamics underlying creative ideation. The blind variation and selective retention framework assumes that creative ideas result from a two-step process — analogous to Darwin’s theory of evolution where genetic variation and natural selection operate”

“involving variations of unguided solution attempts and subsequent selection of potentially improved solutions32,54. Similarly, the Geneplore framework proposes that creative thinking involves repeated cycles of generative and explorative phases83. Thus, there is broad theoretical agreement that the temporal dynamics underlying creative ideation involve at least two iteratively running stages which are commonly termed idea generation and idea evaluation84.”

“The seminal associative theory of creativity, dating back to the 1960s35, argued that individual differences in semantic memory structure influence creative thought24,68,191. It proposed that creative individuals are characterized by ‘flat’ associative hierarchies (numerous and weakly related associations to a given concept) rather than ‘steep’ associative hierarchies (few and strong associations to a given concept) in semantic memory. Direct evidence for the associative theory has long been lacking112. However, driven by the application of computational network science methodology, the role of semantic memory structure in facilitating individual differences in creative ideation has been increasingly elucidated over the past few years23. Several computational modelling studies have demonstrated how a ‘flexible’ semantic memory network structure — a structure where concepts are closer to each other and more richly connected (that is, a network with lower average shortest path length, lower modularity and higher clustering) — is conducive to higher creative ability24,26,112,192. Individual differences in semantic memory network structure also predicted real-life creative behaviour26,131 and were associated with switching behaviour during memory search93 and the intrinsic connectivity structure of the default, control and salience networks in the brain26,93. Thus, individual variation in semantic memory structure has an important ‘bottom-up’ role in how information is spontaneously accessed and associated during idea generation”

“Consistent with available theorizing, idea generation and idea evaluation are considered the two central iterative creative ideation stages in this framework: candidate solutions are produced during idea generation, which are subsequently evaluated for their creative quality during idea evaluation (Fig. 2). Importantly, the MemiC framework proposes that each central creative ideation stage can be further divided into two separable stages that differ in how memory is recruited.”

“real-life creative ideation case studies have documented known solutions retrieved from memory being effectively adapted to new problems29,34 (for example, Watson and Crick adopting, among others, Pauling’s insights on the spiral structures within protein configurations to elucidate the double helix structure of DNA)90, consistent with the expertise view of creativity and empirical evidence on opportunistic assimilation91, analogical mapping92 and exploitation strategies93,94. Yet the retrieved information from memory might also initially appear unrelated to the problem but still be potentially relevant to it (for example, Kekulé imagining a snake biting its tail inspiring the finding of the hexagonal structure of benzene)95, consistent with the remote associates view35 and the executive theory of creativity49 the former view focusing on bottom-up search processes and the latter on top-down search processes — and with empirical evidence on Janusian thinking96 and exploration strategies97,98.”

“In the next stage of idea generation, the retrieved information from memory gets linked to the problem via the construction of new connections. For conceptual ideation tasks — tasks that essentially rely on the manipulation of semantic information — this construction stage can be achieved with the identification of novel or indirect semantic associations between problem and target concepts99. By contrast, for ideation tasks that involve more complex forms of imagination — tasks relying on dynamic, multimodal representations such as object manipulations or entire scenes — this construction stage is expected to implicate episodic construction processes, which enable individuals to imagine plausible ways of integrating new information into given problem scenarios71,100.”

“Let us further illustrate the stages of the MemiC framework with an example from a classic creative ideation task, the alternate uses task102 (Fig. 2, bottom). The alternate uses task assesses divergent thinking by requiring individuals to find creative uses for everyday object problem cues such as a ‘car tyre’5 (Fig. 2). Individuals use various memory search strategies when generating potential creative uses for problem cues on the alternate uses task47,103. For instance, using a property-based strategy, individuals search their memory for an object that shares characteristic properties with the problem cue (for example, objects that are round and dark share characteristics of a car tyre). Individuals then try to construct object uses by connecting the problem cue (car tyre) with the retrieved objects (round and dark objects), which can be as simple as running an episodic simulation attempting object replacement104 (trying to replace the retrieved objects with a car tyre). The constructed candidate solutions are then subjected to an evaluation of novelty and effectiveness.”

“the outlined four-stage process captured within the MemiC framework should equally apply to other strategies in the alternate uses task (for example, disassembly use, where object parts are considered for original reuse)47 as well as to other divergent thinking tasks, both abstract (for example, the consequences task asking individuals to think of creative consequences of a utopian scenario, such as that humans no longer require sleep)106 and realistic (for example, creative reappraisal of an emotionally evocative event, such as an argument with a friend)107.”

“higher broad retrieval ability110 — the ability to fluently retrieve information from semantic memory — substantially predicts creative ideation performance (that is, divergent thinking) across different broad retrieval tasks such as letter fluency, category fluency and associative fluency (these tasks ask individuals to retrieve words for given initial letters, for categories or based on semantic relatedness, respectively)41,43,47,111.”
“The broad retrieval–divergent thinking relation holds after controlling for the influence of mental speed44 and of crystallized intelligence113,114.”

“creative ideation has also been related to the retrieval from memory of more remote, weak associations indicated by higher semantic distance115 — a computational measure of concept dissimilarity. In free association and association chaining, the generation of more distant verbs116, adjectives49 and even unrelated words117, as well as the production of more remote associations, is associated with higher creative performance118,119. Finally, analyses of creative ideation performance over time revealed distinct strategies that guide search during idea generation (clustering and switching; exploration and exploitation)48,97,120,121, again pointing to the strategic nature of this process. In summary, these findings show that creative ideation is facilitated by controlled search and the retrieval of many, often remote, associative elements.”

“greater amounts of episodic detail when imagining future autobiographical events was associated with higher divergent thinking performance on the alternate uses task57,122 and the consequences task123 (another test of divergent thinking).”

“Selective disruption of hippocampal brain networks by transcranial magnetic stimulation reduced both the number of episodic details during a future simulation task and the fluency of idea production on the alternate uses task62. Similarly, direct cortical stimulation of nodes in the default mode network (a neural system supporting imagination and mental simulation)13,126 in the exposed brain during presurgical preparation resulted in reduced fluency but not originality during performance of the alternate uses task127. Thus, episodic memory retrieval appears to have a selective role supporting ideational fluency not originality, suggesting that episodic memory provides candidate ideas which then require further processing to ensure their creative quality (that is, their novelty and effectiveness). However, prior work does not support a simplistic view of episodic memory as merely recalling known or old ideas in creative ideation, as episodic specificity induction boosted the generation of both new and old ideas on the alternate uses task123.”

“Abundant evidence supports the notion that constructing semantic links facilitates creative ideation. For example, the ability to generate numerous and original associative combinations predicts creative ideation performance, independent of the ability to retrieve original associations43,129. Similarly, performance in the remote associates test35 — a task requiring individuals to find semantic relations between three seemingly unrelated concepts (for instance, cheese would be the solution if given cottage, blue and cake as cottage cheese, blue cheese and cheesecake provide semantic relations between the terms) — is widely considered to be an index of creative ability130.”

“Interestingly, creative individuals judge remote concepts in relatedness judgement tasks as more related, suggesting that creative individuals are more sensitive to subtle, indirect semantic relationships131,132.”

“Evidence indicates that episodic simulation is another powerful mechanism supporting constructive thought57,122. Episodic simulation refers to the flexible recombination of multimodal information to create complex mental simulations — episodic constructions — and is viewed as central to spontaneous forms of imagination such as in mind wandering and dreaming21,72, as well as goal-directed forms of imagination such as future thinking and creative ideation3,71.”

“Long-term memory has been historically divided into the functionally distinct systems of semantic and episodic memory. Whereas semantic memory refers to general conceptual knowledge about the meaning of words and objects reflecting their semantic relatedness (for example, street is more related to car than to apple)66, episodic memory refers to the collection of autobiographic events reflecting contextualized, multimodal experiences where concepts co-occur in time and space (for example, witnessing a car accident on the street last weekend)193,194. Furthermore, the functional distinction between these memory types is supported by neuroimaging and clinical evidence. Semantic memory has been associated with brain networks spanning the inferior frontal cortex, posterior middle temporal gyrus and inferior parietal sulcus195, whereas episodic memory has been associated with networks spanning the posterior cingulate cortex, angular gyrus and medial temporal lobe196.”

“Notwithstanding these brain network differences, semantic memory and episodic memory have been increasingly recognized as interrelated memory types197,198. For instance, semantic and episodic memory share neural retrieval mechanisms associated with the left inferior frontal gyrus and the anterior insular cortex199,200. Further work indicated that semantic memory affected the encoding of new episodic memories136. Hence, semantic memory is now thought to support the organization of information during episodic memory acquisition and reconstruction by serving as a scaffold for episodic memory4,21,182.”

“Individuals are reasonably discerning in evaluating the creativity of their own ideas and of others’ ideas142,143 and their judgement strongly relies on the perceived novelty of ideas (the correlation between evaluations of novelty and evaluations of overall creativity are in the range of r = 0.80)87,144,145. Yet individuals exhibiting higher creativity, domainspecific expertise and openness to new experiences are consistently more discerning in idea evaluation146–148, suggesting that having more diverse and relevant experiences supports more accurate novelty judgements (for example, not misattributing known uncommon ideas as being novel). This notion is consistent with openness to new experiences being the strongest personality predictor of creative ideation performance149. Moreover, higher openness is associated with a more ‘flexible’ semantic memory structure150 and with higher efficiency of information processing in the default mode network151,152.”

“udging the effectiveness of novel ideas — or newly designed products — might not be achieved with memory retrieval alone but might also involve episodic (mental) simulations applying the idea (or product) under various contexts to test how well given affordances are met103,165. Effectiveness judgements also take longer for novel compared with familiar ideas, which lends further support to the notion that additional episodic simulation processes are taking place166,167.”

“The MemiC framework does not claim that creative ideation always follows all four stages in a constant linear sequence (for example, there may be considerable back and forth between search and construction before a candidate idea arises that can be subjected to evaluation) but, rather, describes crucial elements of creative ideation that build on each other and unfold in an iterative fashion over time. Explicit substages are further useful for understanding how cognitive activities map onto relevant processes. For example, when creative ideation is performed under ‘be fluent’ instructions171 — which emphasizes idea quantity over quality — and, more generally, during brainstorming172 which encourages coming up with many ‘wild’ ideas without considering their immediate feasibility — effectiveness evaluations might only have a minimal role.”
